--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "John L. Webber - Jentro AG" 
<John.Webber@j...> wrote:
> For quite a while I used the static inner classes technique, but 
found 
> that with time our source files were getting too cluttered.

What do you mean by "cluttered".  I just put the inner class at the 
bottom of the source file.  The demarcation of app code and the test 
code is very clear.

> I've now moved to putting my test cases in a parallel directory 
with the 
> same package structure,

Don't you find it more of a hassle to manage seperate files, in 
seperate directories, especially while checking your code in and out 
of a source code repository?  What if you forget to check in the test 
code?  Presumably you could script this, but that's just another 
hassle.


> and if I really need to test a private method I 
> change the access to package-private and can then test it directly 
from 
> a test class in the same package, but in a different source tree. 
With a 
> few good Ant targets and/or scripts this works nicely. Still, 
changing a 
> private method representing an implementation detail to package-
private 
> seems to be a code smell!

Amen.


Mike
